body:
The Court of Protection protect individuals who lack capacity under the Mental Capacity Act.

The Court of Protection makes decisions financial or welfare matters for people who can’t make decisions at the time they need to be made (they ‘lack mental capacity’). 

The court will decide whether someone has the mental capacity to make a particular decision for themselves, and appoint deputies to make ongoing decisions for people who lack mental capacity.

A deputy is someone who makes decisions on someone's behalf if they lack capacity.

Deputies are supervised but the Office of the Public Guardian (OPG). They will visit the deputy and check they are carrying out their duties properly and have the right level of support.

Deputies must keep bank statements and receipts. They also must write a report each year explaining the decisions they’ve made as a deputy and sent it to the OPG.

**What you need to do**

Use this form to tell the Court of Protection whether you agree or disagree with a property and financial affairs application.

[respond-deputy.application.service.justice.gov.uk](respond-deputy.application.service.justice.gov.uk)

It usually takes about 5 minutes.

You have 14 days from the day you were told about the application to complete this form.

If you can't complete form online, or you need more time to respond you can complete the paper form:

[gov.uk/government/publications/apply-to-be-part-of-court-of-protection-proceedings-form-cop5](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/apply-to-be-part-of-court-of-protection-proceedings-form-cop5)

And post it to:

Court of Protection
PO Box 70185
First Avenue House
42-49 High Holborn
London
WC1A 9JA
